lines.text: [Talking about naming Del's baby]
If it's a girl they're gonna name it Sigourney, after the actress. And if it's a boy they're gonna name him Rodney, after Dave.
If there is such a thing as reincarnation, knowing my luck I'll come back as me.
Trigger what are you doing here?
Well Dave, Del Boy said he'd give me a lift down the pub.
Oh I suppose that's... Hold on, you live closer to the pub then we do?
Yeah I know, but Del Boy said he'd give me a lift down the pub.
But Trigger, you've had walk past the pub to get to our flat!
I know, but Del Boy said he'd give me a lift down the pub.
Where d'you get those aces from?
Same place you got those kings. I always knew you were cheating, Boycie.
Yeah, how?
'Cause that wasn't the hand that I dealt you.
Don't worry, Rodney. This time next year, we'll be millionaires!
This time last WEEK we were millionaires!
During the war...

[interupts Albert]
If you say during the war one more time, I'll pour this cup of tea over your head.
During the 1939-1945 conflict with Germany.
[about making a film called "There's a Rhino loose in the city"]
It's a love story and a who done it!
Everyone knows who done it! There's 30 dead people with Rhino tramps all over them, there's a lock up with 2 foot pile of Rhino dung and Charlton Heston suspects the butler!
What you up to Dave?
I'm listening to Mozart's Concerto No.5 in D-Minor.
No words to this song Dave?
No Trigger, it's an instrumental.
All right Trigger? What you doing?
I'm listening to Mozart's Concerto No.5 in D-Minor.
Okay.
It's the karaoke version.
Problems, Dave?
I don't want to talk about it Trig. You ever been wrongly accused of something?
Yeah once.
Yeah, How did you get out of it?
Well I didn't - I was guilty.
Your dad always said that one day Del Boy would reach the top. Then again, he always said Millwall would win the cup.
Are you saying I'm stupid?
Either that or it's the Chinese year of the dodo.
What're you doing?
I'm trying to get the Dukes of Hazzard.
The Dukes of... That is a microwave oven, you dozy old twonk! Gordon Bennett, you'll be putting frozen pizzas into the portable next!
Your name Rodney, son?
Well, it is when Trigger's not about!
Is that the radio I hear, Rodney?
No, Elton John popped in and he's rehearsing in the kitchen!
I see ICI dropped a point.
Yeah. Chelsea dropped three on Saturday
When we was at school Del was the best at Chemistry. He used to sell home-made fireworks. He even blew up the science lab once.
Yes I remember. I was doing detention in there at the time.

[Del and Rodney are trying to sell Mike a computer]
What exactly does that mean?
Well it means you can... you can... tell him what it means, Rodney.
[to Mike]
He's taken a course in this, he came top of his class.
Well, in 'layman's' terms it means you can, em, well, you er, you can record all your business deals.
I spend half my life trying to hide my business deals. So the last thing I want is to have 'em all recorded on a floppy bloody disc! I'm not interested. Ask Trigger.
Trigger? With a computer? Do me a favour, he's still struggling with light switches!
We didn't know the fancy dress had been cancelled.
Me neither.
You mean, that's your costume?
Yeah. I came as a chauffeur. I feel a bit stupid now.
Yeah, you do stand out.
I don't think I'll ever laugh again.
Well, as long as yer 'appy, son.
He who dares Rodney, he who dares.

[referring to a pile of broken lawnmower engines]
Oi, Del... me and Mickey might have a problem getting these back to our depot. We come down on the Green Line, see?
Right, well, your best bet would be to hire an open-backed truck.
Oh, yeah, yeah, that's what we thought, but... we were wondering if you could take a couple in the back of the van.
Back of my van? You must be joking. I've only just cleared 'em out of the van!
You mean you were selling 'em in the first place?

Yeah. That is the rubbish that Alfie Flowers sold me last week. Normally I'd never have bought it but, you know, he caught me when I was a bit non compost mentis down the one-eleven club. I never thought I'd get shot of 'em, Rodney, but you know me; he who dares wins. I actually made quite a tidy little profit on it and all.
And what are we supposed to do with them?
Well, why don't you do what I did? Find yourselves a couple of right little plonkers with cash on the hip.

[after Uncle Albert's suggested Rodney put himself up as a hooker]
Rodney can't even *give* it away, let alone flog it!

[after getting his old job back at Trotters Independent Traders]
What will be my title?
We'll call you Lord Rodney!
I meant company title!
[after realizing Delboy was going a little bit TOO far out on the ocean on a Jet-Ski]
He's going a long way out!
Yeah! But he's enjoying himself!
Yeah I know that but Del can't even swim.
BUT I THOUGHT HE SAID HE HAD A CERTIFICATE FOR SWIMMING!
Well he does... but it ain't his!
Now. Where's my bottle of wine?
Blimey. Captain Birds Eye's here in all.
Keep the noise down will yer, I can hardly hear this!
Shut up you saucy old git.
Well, even if you could hear it, you couldn't understand it, could you, it's in Indian!
In 1959 I was in Bombay!
You carry on much longer by tomorrow afternoon you could be in traction.
But I like this kind of music!
Ah! Oh yeah, look at that Rodney. It's one of his favourites that is. That's that good old fashioned sing-along number, Knees Up Mother Patel.

[to Del]
You were declared bankrupt. You have been banned from running any company from sitting on any boards or dealing with any shares. They don't even want you past the Stock Exchange on a bike! And you owe the Inland Revenue over £50,000.
If Elsie Partridge really could raise the dead half the money lenders in Peckham would be employing her.
There's no point in running away. Running away only wears out your shoes.
Did you play cards again last night?
What? Yes! You know me Grandad! He who dares, wins.
How'd you get on?
I lost.

[talking about how to get a date with a beautiful woman]
Just be yourself.
Oh, leave it out, Rodney; I wanna be in with at least half a chance!

[after he and Mickey Pearce have bought a heap of broken lawnmower engines]
Oi, you! This stuff is a load of rubbish!
I know. I did try to warn you.
Well... yeah... but I thought ...
Yeah, well, the trouble with you, Rodney, is that you will insist on thinking!

[Del has had a hang-gliding accident and is in a wheelchair surrounded by sympathetic well-wishers]
Oh, listen to me for one minute, will you? Hospitals do not send home paralysed people by bus!

[lunging to his feet and seizing Rodney around the neck]
You listen to me, you little git! I may never walk again! I may...
[realises]
Though I must admit I'm getting some feeling back.

[Grandad is talking to an urn containing the ashes of Trigger's grandfather]
I mean, I dunno why I'm even talking to you about this, Arthur, 'cause I know you can't hear me.

[picking up a traffic cone and using it as a loudspeaker]
That is what *you* think, Trotter!
Arthur? You mean... you can hear me?
You're coming through louder than a CB. Rubber duck.
Oh, Arthur, I... I really am sorry about what happened all them years ago.
Ah, but how do I know that you mean it?
Oh, I do, Arthur. I'd do anything to prove it to you.
All right then. Tell me where your money's hidden.
I ain't got no money!
Oh, don't give me that, you lying old git! I know you're all right for a few bob, and I want to know where it is hidden.
It's in me suitcase under me bed.
No it ain't; I've looked.
They might publish your diaries one day, Del. I reckon that could be a winner. I don't believe you sometimes! Why did you do that?
He Who Dares Wins, I've always been the same!
Well, this time I reckon that He Who Dared cocked it right up!
Albert, you must have come back with more medals than the Russian Olympic squad!
Oh I didn't ask for 'em! They kept giving 'em to me!

[to Del after seeing Del-Boy punch out her flatmate]
Why the hell did you do that?
It's all right, it's all right, it's all right, Raquel. It's all right. You don't have to be frightened of the Great Ramondo no more - Del Boy is here?
[whistles the opening bar to "The Good, The Bad and The Ugly"]
During the 1939-1945 conflict with Germany - I was sailing on a frigate, HMS Sphinx, in the Adriatic. Now in those days a ship's crew was full of stress and fear.
Especially when they saw you walking up the gangplank!
So our old skipper, Captain Kenworthy, used to allay all those fears by creating a counter-worry. Like one day he announced there was a cholera epidemic on the ship.
I bet that cheered you all up, didn't it?
It took their minds off the U-boats and sharks.
Well, thanks for that, Unc. It's lucky your Captain Kenworthy never became a Samaritan. You wouldn't be able to get a tug under Chelsea Bridge for falling bodies!

[to Rodney]
You uncaring little git! I could be on me last knockings here and you don't give a toss if I've got yellow fever or foot-fungus!

[talking about one of Del's mates]
That bloke's come on a bundle in the last few years. That man is at the front of new technological frontiers. He's got a Queen's Award for industry plaque and all.
I know. I was there when you sold it to him.
I've been thinking.
Oh, leave it out Rodney, we're in enough trouble as it is.

[talking to the Police]
Rodney's got a police record!

[quickly]
Yes, er... it's "Walking on the Moon".
Cos-mic.
I could do with another blanket here, I'm freezing.
Yeah it is a bit cold.
Cold? You bits of kids don't know the meaning of the word. You should have been with me on the Russian convoys. One night it was so cold the flame on my lighter froze.

[after getting off a plane in Spain for winning a contest that is not all that legit]
Well, before we get checked in I have gotta tell you something Rodney. This contest isn't quite as pucker as I made it out to be.
Well he did win didn't he?

[looking at the other winners]
That's strange that is.
What is?
Well I noticed it on the plane but it didn't quite register. Their all Mum's and Dad's. They have brought their kids with them.
It's not the parents who are the winners Rodder's... it's the kids. You see Rodney's painting won... in the under 15 years old category.
So they think Rodney's 15?
Nah! No, No, No. They think your 14!

[pointing at Uncle Albert]
Well it's his fault isn't it?

[to Del]
What's he on about now?
Oh I don't bleedin know, do I?
Look, every single battleship, cruiser and merchant ship he ever sailed on either got torpedoed of dive-bombed... and two of them in peace-time! I'm telling you Del, that man is a jinx!
Oh leave it out Rodney. You'll be burning Witches next!
I keep all the stuff I never intend to see in this old shed.
Why have you got this deep sea divers suit for, Del?
I bought it so you can go down and visit all the ships you sailed on you git!
Del, there is a drought warning over Peckham!
Sit down, Rodney. Keep your brains warm.
Now look Rodney, Raquel, Raquel is a lady and when a lady is ready to... well, when she's ready to, she will let me know.
How?
Well, she'll give me a sign or something.
Like what?

[thinks]
I dunno.
Maybe she'll put an announcement in the Sunday Sport.
Eat your breakfast, Del.

[looking at the plate]
I thought the doctor said all this fried stuff was bad for my veins?
Eat your breakfast, Del!

[after looking at an old WW2 photo of Uncle Albert's]
Just a few hours after that photo was taken we was in action.
That's all you need, innit?

There was an American aircraft-carrier, anchored off-shore. The USS Pittsburgh. It was our job to protect her. Well, we'd only been sailing for about an hour and we crashed right into her. Cor, didn't half make a noise.

[incredulous]
You went and whacked into the boat that you were going out to protect?
Yeah. It was a good job she was there actually, she picked up most of the survivors.
Was your ship badly damaged?
*We* couldn't tell, Rodney, it sunk! Course, they tried to put the blame on me.
Sounds fair.
Just 'cos I was on watch at the time. I had me excuses ready!
What, were you drunk?
Don't be silly! The American vessel was at battle stations and was showing no light. You weren't allowed. There was a war on.
Course there was.
So then they tried to get me on naval technicalities, like it happened in broad daylight.
You didn't see an aircraft carrier?
Forty-two thousand tons of steel!
Well I wasn't close enough!
You must have been reasonably close. Unc, you hit it!
They'd have stood more chance with Ray Charles in the crow's nest!
Oh, no, Raquel. You must never lose sight of your dream! When I was 18, I decided I was gonna be a millionaire by the time I was 21.
Really?
Yep... and when I was 21, I said I'd be a millionaire by the time I was 30... and when I was 30...
[referring to the biscuits]
Fancy a Jammy-Dodger?
Have you ever thought about joining the navy, Rodney?
Well, funnily enough, Unc, *no*! How could I join the navy?
Exactly. In the old days they'd take anyone - well, they took you! But nowadays, you've gotta have a cotchel of qualifications.
[pointing to Rodney]
I mean, what chance would Lawrence of Peckham stand?

I don't mean in the Royal navy. I was talking about the merchant. Just imagine it, Rodney. Monday, you sail out of Southhampton Water. Tuesday, you're through the Bay of Biscay. Wednesday, you've rounded Cape St Vincent. Thursday, you dock in Algiers...

[cutting in]
And Friday it's your turn in the barrel!

[distressed]
Eh?
There was nothing like that on any of my vessels! A few funny ones but nothing like that!
Er... well... I'm a good salesman.
Do me a favor, Rodney! You couldn't flog a black cat to a witch!
Oh, leave it out Rodney, you couldn't flog a black cat to a witch!

I have become dismayed, even shocked by the attitude of youth - but today you walked into this church and offered us this tree simply because you care. You have rekindled my faith in the human race. It's not nicked, is it?
[Del Boy is trying to sell Christmas trees to him]
Now, as the Bible says, 'Clothes maketh the man'.
The Paki shop won't let us have nothing on tick! Says it's part of his culture!
Don't think it's got anything to do with the 46 quid we already owe 'em do you?

[after seeing what Rodney had bought with the company money]
What's the weather like out?
It's parky, Del!

[sarcastic]
Good, good! Nice thick frost is there?
Bit slippery underfoot, yeah!
Oh, cushty! Nice notherly wind howling in from the Urals is there?
Cut's right through you, Del!

Lovely! Because today, Uncle Albert, owing to young Rodney's foresight and GCEs, while all them other plonkers down the market are selling woolly hats and thermal under-wear, we're gonna make a right killing. Do you know why we're gonna make a right killing? We ain't got woolly underwear!
[produces bottle from box]
*We've* got sun-tan lotion! And we ain't got just a little drop of sun-tan lotion! We've got 500 bloody quids' worth of the stuff!
I've told you, I bought it as an investment!
An Investment! Menage a trois! In the middle of the worst winter for 2 million years, with the weatherman laying odds on a new Ice Age - this dipstick goes out and buys out Amber Solaire!

I was reading in the Sunday papers about them fellas that pick up with these rich old widows - what they call 'em - toy boys! You wanna see the stuff they pick up for presents. Solid gold watches, sports cars - money! Might be worth considering!

[Del and Rodney give each other weird glances]
Well, we both admire your spirit, Uncle, but don't you think you've left it a bit late for that sort of thing?
I'm not talking about me! I meant you!

[incredulous]
Me? I'm not selling my body to some old tart! Thank you!
Not even for the family?
Especially not for the family! I'm not going to let myself become some... hooker!

[after Rodney goes on a date with a Policewoman]
You know what the most sobering thought of all is? One wrong word from that plonker Rodney and I could end up doing five years!
Oi, Del, why'd they call him Trigger? Does he carry a gun or something?
Na, it's coz he looks like an horse.

[after buying defective briefcases]
So how do you open these then?
No sod knows, Rodney, that's why they're rejects!

[taking the rise out of Rodney wanting to get a job]
Yes, sir, I have qualifications. I have two GCE's, a suspended sentence and I know a good joint when I puffed one!
Del, let's just get out! Before I wake up with a bloody horses ead' on me pillow!
Rodney, it's for you.
[passes the phone to him]
Who is it?
Richard Branston.
If I get piles you can have half of 'em!

[is trying to impress]
I say, how do you spell 'Arrods?
Capital A.
Yes, capital... oh. Oh, right. Yes. Beam me up, Snotty.
Who are you after? Oh, not the Gruesome Twosome. They're so ugly they even look alike.
They happen to be two sisters.
Oh, sisters?
[to women]
Hey, girls, seen much of Cinderella since the wedding?

[Rodney is looking for crimes to report at the tenants' meeting]
Well, why don't you tell them what happened to poor Rita Alldridge then?
Yes! Good idea! What happened to Rita Alldridge then?
Last Friday night she was indecently assaulted over by the adventure playground.
No! Did she report it?
Yeah, I saw her this morning, she'd just been down the police station.
Right. There you are, you see; that's exactly the sort of thing... hang on a minute, if this happened on Friday night, how come it's taken her 'til Wednesday to report it?
Because she didn't know she'd been indecently assaulted until this morning when the bloke's cheque bounced.
Lovely jubbly!
